body:
as for reflection: it's really not the same.

the patch is using that technique, for simple cases.

but with hints, you can add messages that are hints and not errors.

I hope I can explain this.

Adding to hints, would give you a big area to talk to users, and those would be different things then reporting the error.

also, there is things like (in en.yml)
    inclusion:
        in: "must be one of %{count}"
     associated: "is invalid"
      uniqueness: "must be unique"
      confirmation: "doesn't match confirmation"
      acceptance: "must be accepted"

compared with

      inclusion: "is not included in the list"
      exclusion: "is reserved"
      invalid: "is invalid"
      confirmation: "doesn't match %{attribute}"
      accepted: "must be accepted"


For example 'inclusion'.
For an error, you want 'Name is not included in the list'
but for a hint you want ' Select a Name from the list'

I hope that is clear enough, it is the same for many other Validators.

You would need separate messages for hints and errors in many occasions.


I agree, by far not all apps would benefit. But it wouldn't hurt either.

I really don't care if you dont' want this in rails. I can live without it, and use the gem validation_hints. (but the other named gems could benefit from that directly!)

I understand that there are much more pressing issues.

But I want to contribute to rails. Please do give me the benefit of the doubt, and needless to say I am very happy with Rafael's reactions after the close.

I just want to be part of this. It took me 5 years to learn RoR and maybe I can do only one pull request per year. Dont dismiss it so easily ( but dismiss it by all means if it is not suitable).

Thx guys (and girls).

Oh and the not so DRY repeating of errors.rb. If I knew how to do that better, I'd do it; I think 80% of that file (errors.rb) could be factored out and just include it in errors.rb and hints.rb (add, delete, all that stuff).

'night.

Ace
